Situation1: Their partner faces a tough decision at work and seeks advice and encouragement.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Late-afternoon errands leave just a couple of hours before the polls close.
Story:
I glanced at the clock, my heart thumping faster as the minutes slipped away. The polling station would close in less than two hours, and I still had groceries to put away. Just as I started to rush, my husband called from the living room, his voice trembling. He’d been agonizing over a work decision for days, and now he needed me—really needed me—to listen, to help him sort through his options. I could see the worry etched on his face, the way his hands fidgeted with his phone. He was counting on me to be his anchor, to offer the support only I could give.

But the thought of missing my chance to vote gnawed at me. I’d promised myself I wouldn’t let anything get in the way this year. Civic duty mattered, and I wanted my voice heard. Yet here I was, torn between being the partner he deserved and the citizen I aspired to be. My chest tightened as I weighed his pleading eyes against the ticking clock, feeling the pressure of both worlds closing in.
